repnme.cdata!:
Dominica, Grenada, St. Lucia, St. Vincent
            and the Grenadines - OECS Catastrophe Insurance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the OECS Catastrophe
            Insurance Project for Dominica, Grenada, St. Lucia, and St.
            Vincent and the Grenadines were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; Bank
            performance was satisfactory; borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: this project
            offered the four Caribbean island countries the opportunity
            to join the first ever regional catastrophe insurance pool
            and thereby secure immediate liquidity in case of a covered
            disaster (earthquakes and hurricane). It is part of a
            broader development agenda of Bank support aimed at reducing
            the vulnerability of the Caribbean island countries to
            natural disasters. After three years of operations, several
            lessons can be drawn from this project. Risk pooling is
            effective in significantly reducing the cost of individual
            countries' financial risk transfer brought insurance.
            Extensive communicator with participants is required not
            only leading up to the facility's inception, but also
            throughout its operations to ensure that its products are we
            understood. Catastrophe insurance is a new tool for many
            Caribbean island countries, and thus requires extensive
            capacity building. Catastrophe Risk financing programs can
            help bridge tile gap among Ministries of Finance and
            agencies involved in disaster risk management. Even The use
            of International Development Association (IDA) resources for
            targeted and· limited subsidies can help countries test and
            establish insurance programs. Rapid claims settlement
            through parametric insurance is feasible and effective. An
            efficient budget execution system is important. The quick
            cash injection following a natural disaster is effective
            only if the country's post-disaster budget execution
            system allows for an immediate use of these funds.

Dominica, Grenada, St. Lucia, St. Vincent
            and the Grenadines - OECS Catastrophe Insurance Project

display_title.display_title:
Dominica, Grenada, St. Lucia, St.
            Vincent and the Grenadines - OECS Catastrophe Insurance Project

13975522.trustfund:
TF055129-PHRD-OECS COUNTRIES: OECS
            CATASTROPHE INSURANCE,TF091243-GFDRR: LAC: CARIBBEAN RISK ATLAS,TF090741-SWITZERLAND CTF - FY08 - ALL

repnme.cdata!:
OECS Countries - Catastrophe Insurance
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Catastrophe
            Insurance Project for Organization of Eastern Caribbean
            States (OECS) Countries is to reduce the participating
            country's financial vulnerability to natural disasters
            (earthquakes and hurricanes). In order to provide for
            reimbursement of 50 percent of the fourth premium for
            2010-2011 out of the proceeds of the credit, the following
            changes are proposed to the financing agreement: (a)
            amendment of the project description to include the fourth
            installment in the second component (part B) of the project;
            (b) modification of the institutional arrangements to
            require a counterpart financing of 50 percent for the fourth
            installment; and (c) modification of the table of
            disbursement (withdrawal of proceeds of the financing), to
            include an additional category for the fourth installment,
            and reallocation of the amount of the credit among
            categories to provide for the amount of the fourth installment.

display_title.display_title:
OECS Countries - Catastrophe
            Insurance Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Proposed trust fund for the Caribbean
            catastrophe risk insurance facility

abstracts.cdata!:
The purpose of this memorandum is to
            propose the establishment o f a multi-donor trust fund (the
            Caribbean Catastrophe Risk Insurance Facility Trust Fund or
            the CCRIF Trust Fund) to channel financial support to the
            Caribbean Catastrophe Risk Insurance Facility (CCRIF), which
            aims to provide Caribbean Community (CARICOM) member or
            associate member countries with a better mechanism for
            dealing with earthquake and hurricane risks. The CCRIF Trust
            Fund will provide financing to cover establishment costs and
            operating expenses, including insurance payouts of the
            CCRIF. Such financing will provide an injection of funds
            during the initial period o f the CCRIF, and help ensure its
            financial viability and long-term sustainability. The CCRIF
            is expected to become self sustainable within five years, by
            which time funding support from the CCRIF Trust Fund is
            expected to cease.

docna.cdata!:
Proposed trust fund for the Caribbean
            catastrophe risk insurance facility

display_title.display_title:
Proposed trust fund for the
            Caribbean catastrophe risk insurance facility
